title: When will a Carnival Cruise Line cruise next depart from the continental U.S.?
preds: https://www.fox35orlando.com/news/carnival-ceo-cruise-demand-exceeds-supply pretty optimistic that they will be ready as of July 3rd or little bit later

Florida took legal action to require the CDC to have cruise lines depart as soon as possible. However, Florida has a new law coming up that would hinder that process, requiring cruise lines to have in essence "vaccine passports." In spite, there are other options for departure ports.

https://news.yahoo.com/floridas-desantis-standoff-cruise-ship-055646353.html
The distinguished Governor of the great state of Florida may yet screw this industry up, at least to the point that they'll have to arrange to sail from some place that isn't Florida.   That might take time to arrange.  I still think this will get sorted by September, though. There is some disagreement about whether you have furniture smarter than the distinguished Governor of the great state of Florida, but it is dead cert that you have furniture that cares more about the economic and physical well-being of humans than he does.  If I could find my U of  F diploma, I'd be tempted to mail it back.
Let's go boating in the big ones, the Fourth is our week!
Based on disqualification of shakedown cruises in this response.  Earliest possible date is June.

I ascertain a small probability that the simulated cruises prove encouraging early and pushes the CDC to allow cruising earlier than mid-July and possibly into June. Likewise, if India's situation spills into the U.S. or nearby sailing ports, I would assume it could further delay things.

Maintaining forecast. Solid evidence for this summer, June at the earliest. The key question is whether the test cruises allowed by the CDC will contain “ticketed passengers” as defined in the question.  https://news.yahoo.com/cruise-lines-apply-sail-volunteer-201000407.html
Currently first cruise up for purchase is July 1st from Galveston Texas (based on their website).

I think the best chance of a grey swan is Carnival Cruise moving the dates earlier to June. However, I do not see that happening because that would mean messing around with the schedule already set out for the year (assumption). In support of this, the CDC also says it can resume in "mid-July," according to news reports. It would be relatively difficult to go against this government guideline.

CDC says they can run by mid-summer if 95% of the turistas and 98% of the crew are fully shot up, eliminating the requirement for test runs.  This will be a great relief to the cruise lines, and especially to the islands suffering the absence of old persons in short pants buying baskets and complaining about the weather.

Update: CDC as reported by WSJ finally seems to come to terms with the Cruise Lines including Carnival.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/cruise-lines-could-start-u-s-sailings-by-mid-july-cdc-says-11619670325 I expect Carnival under the helm of an competent CEO like Mr. Arnold Donald to be ready by then and capitalize on the ealiest possible date. Since mid July to end of september - the relevant time slot -  is still a healthy margin of safety i believe the likelihoood that we see a different outcome is low. Carnival needs these revenues and will start earliest possible date.

Currently bookings are open for three different itineries of short trips from Miami, FL to the Bahamas in July:
Departing 08 Jul 2021
https://www.carnival.com/itinerary/4-day-the-bahamas-cruise/miami/sunrise/4-days/baf?abCode=&currency=USD&hideSailingEvents=true&itinportcode=mia&locality=1&military=N&numGuests=2&offerCode=&pastGuest=N&promoCode=&rateCode=&roomType=IS&sailDate=07082021&senior=N&smp=Y
09 Jul 2021
https://www.carnival.com/itinerary/3-day-the-bahamas-cruise/miami/conquest/3-days/bag?abCode=&currency=USD&hideSailingEvents=true&itinportcode=mia&locality=1&military=N&numGuests=2&offerCode=&pastGuest=N&promoCode=&rateCode=&roomType=IS&sailDate=07092021&senior=N&smp=Y
26 Jul 2021
https://www.carnival.com/itinerary/4-day-the-bahamas-cruise/miami/conquest/4-days/baf?abCode=&currency=USD&hideSailingEvents=true&itinportcode=mia&locality=1&military=N&numGuests=2&offerCode=&pastGuest=N&promoCode=&rateCode=&roomType=IS&sailDate=07262021&senior=N&smp=Y One more adds from 05 August 2021
https://www.carnival.com/itinerary/4-day-the-bahamas-cruise/miami/sunrise/4-days/baf?abCode=&currency=USD&hideSailingEvents=true&itinportcode=mia&locality=1&military=N&numGuests=2&offerCode=&pastGuest=N&promoCode=&rateCode=&roomType=IS&sailDate=08052021&senior=N&smp=Y

Moving up to +2 for July to September sailing based on the industry's capitulation for an earlier sailing time frame.  The CDC recommendations for cruise lines to lift the no sail order creates high hurdles for the companies: crew members having single cabins, for example.[1]  I can't imagine it is possible to run a cruise in that manner.   It seems to me an important point of reference for the CDC's decision will be the race between the rate of vaccination to reach herd immunity and the spread of the new variants.  We can't really know what September and October will look like yet since there are so many contingencies.  I imagine the White House will allow the CDC to use its best collective scientific judgment of when it is safe to resume cruising, despite the lobbying campaign from the governor of Florida and the cruise industry. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/cruise/management/technical-instructions-for-cruise-ships.html

Update since last forcast: All industries open up since vaccination plus good concepts are provided for stopping the spread of Covid 19 in the US successfully. Besides the cruise industry all sector profit. The pressure is mounting on the CDC which insist on leaving the conditional no sail order in place until November. I believe they will crumble and therefore adjusted heavily to the period from July to September so this industry gets pro business support as well. I believe lawsuits on the way in the next months in case CDC blocks them any longer since there is no need any longer. CDC left themselves a face saving backdoor by saying there is some interagency dialogue going on that means Commerce Departmen etc. feel the pressure from the lobby. There wil be a compromise in favour for cruise lines.

Cdc issued uodated technical guidance fkr cruising with covid https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/s0402-conditional-sail-orders.html . Basically it is moving a step closer to cruises occurring.  Still need to do the simulated cruise, but it looks like the cdc wants to dacioitate a restart albeit while covering its ass.

Given the cdc guidance that vaccinated people can travel low risk challenges the top bucket.  It is easy to envision cruises to nowhere with vaccinated people only.  Would be politically interesting if CDC said use vaccine passport to confirm a covid antiben test to bkard aship in Miami. What would De Santis do?
They may not go anywhere, but they will be running and filling the ships on cruises to nowhere sooner rather than later.
Shifting estimate back in time due to rise of new cases and variants.

+6 for sailing 1 July through 30 September, 2021 based on today's WaPo article on the cruise industry pressing for allowing U.S. cruises by July 1 "in keeping with the President's call for a return to normalcy by July 4." [1]  Against my view, the cruise industry admits in the article that they still do not have a common view on vaccinations being required or not to board a ship.  In any event, the probability of sailings before 1 July approaches zero, in my view, based on the cruise industry's own goal, which capitulates on an April, May, or June launch. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/2021/03/24/cruise-cdc-ban-july-vaccine/?itid=hp_dontmiss
Cruise ships not sailing this year.

Carnival Corp. CEO Arnold Donald didn’t give any exact dates for a return to cruising – either for test voyages or revenue operations – but did say it’s possible some cruising will resume by year’s end. CEO of Carnival: “What I will predict is this: I think that certainly by the end of this year, most, if not all, of our fleet, I’m optimistic, will be in action,” Donald said during a webcast “Fireside Chat” with John Lovell, president of Travel Leaders Group. “I think there’s a really high probability that all of them will be back by early next year if things continue to progress the way they have.” https://www.travelpulse.com/news/cruise/carnival-ceo-predicts-when-entire-fleet-when-will-return-discusses-covid-19-vaccine-requirements.html

Excerpt from below link:  Last month,  Truist Securities analyst Patrick Scholes wrote in a note that U.S. cruise ships could remain docked into 2022, though it is more likely cruises will resume later this year. “We now see July as the Best Case for restart,” though the fourth quarter is more likely, he wrote.  https://www.marketwatch.com/story/carnival-plans-to-sell-1-billion-in-fresh-stock-as-cruise-ships-remain-in-the-docks-11614030118  carnival-cruise-line-extends-pause-from-us-through-may-2021 https://mynbc15.com/news/local/carnival-cruise-line-extends-pause-from-us-through-may-2021
Vaccinated only cruises are coming soon.
update to the original forcast due to high rate of vaccination, that were not on the horizont during the first forcast. Adjustment justified.

I believe that most of the cruise lines, including Carnival, are at the mercy of politicians  and experts respectively their assessment of the situations of Covid and policies deriving from that. In itself 1st of July would have been a reasonable and justifyable date to open up the businesses again. The factors influencing mainly will be
-	Cases of CVOID 19 – absolute and relative numbers ( in favor of opening up until July since numbers are going down dramatically in last few weeks for several reasons)
-	Number of vaccinated people in the US ( positive trend for opening up at July with 1.5 million people daily)
-	Politics – Biden promised and wants to be seen as tough on Corona – to make a statement versus Trump and not so business friendly ( negative with respect to opening up before July) In sum I believe societal reasons and hard numbers would justify opening up in July but perception and ego protection by politician need to be weighed higher in these circumstance. Once the decision is passed to CDC and giving a new order / adjusting the new framework another 30 to 60 days will pass, as stated in the CDC document   https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/pdf/CDC-Conditional-Sail-Order_10_30_2020-p.pdf Factors within Carnival control: 20 % of making it happen to open up will depend on Carnvial itself
Since they have a  competent CEO they will do so in 90 % of cases quickly and efficiently So best case: From now on: 6 – 8 weeks of delaying by politician / to evaluate, then CDC in the driver´s seat and then Carnival needs to adjust quickly in the positive direction.
Updates necessary  with regard to positive surprises for vaccination, COVID Cases, seasonal factor in autumn / winter and the response by CDC to these factors.
Update to original forecast based on time passed, a lack of cruise company PRs, and slower than expected vaccine distribution in the midst of newly identified COVID strains.

Multiple of Carnival's ships need to undergo maintenance and the company is canceling most cruises through September. (https://www.carnivalcruiseline.de/en/latest-news-about-corona) The rise of new variants of COVID-19 will continue to delay the resumption of cruises from the United States. Cruises will most likely resume towards the end of 2021.

Most cruise lines have cancelled trips through June or July, but as more vaccines become available early Fall 2021 could see the first Carnival cruise ship sailing again, with limited passengers and activities, but requiring vaccines for all passengers and staff.   https://thepointsguy.com/guide/when-cruise-ships-lines-resume/
Feels as though there is a low likelihood prior to the summer, but think there is a pretty solid chance of it happening this summer.

Currently, the US is struggling with vaccinations and infections of COVID-19. Until vaccinations have been administered and infections go down, there is no way for this to reasonably possible. However, as vaccines are administered and infections decline, this becomes increasingly possible.
Very small chance in the first 100 days of the Biden Administration, as they seem very focused on mask-wearing and social distancing.
Expect higher vaccination rates required and a risk-sensitive corporate inertia

If progress remains linear, its unlikely that a cruise would depart CONUS during Q1. 
Based on CDC guidance, a cruise ship will be cleared to sail when one of the following items is met: 
-The expiration of the Secretary of Health and Human Services’ declaration that COVID-19 constitutes a public health emergency,
-The CDC Director rescinds or modifies the order based on specific public health or other considerations, or
-November 1, 2021.  I think it is only a matter of time before the CDC gives a blessing to vaccinated cruises, likely to happen sometime during Q2/3/4 (meaning part 2 of the conditional order would be met).  I think the least likely scenario is that it gets pushed into CY22...In DOD alone, ~180,000 have already received at least a first dose.

The CDC's conditional sailing order (CSO) is currently the only thing stopping cruise lines from sailing (listening to their most recent earnings call, its clear they have customer's willing to buy ticks, and they dgaf about putting their customers out on the water during a pandemic). 
The CSO basically provides a bunch of new things cruise lines must do in order to be allowed back on the water, and the culmination of them is a cruise trial run, which has real passengers who have volunteered and are aware of the risks. I believe the trial run would leave from a continental US port, and qualify for this question.
Carnival doesn't have a trial run you can sign up for, but royal carribean got 100,000+ signups for their as yet unscheduled trial run.
It is conceivable to me that the trial run could be filled with only vaccinated guests (this isn't currently a req) before april 1, but the biggest hurdle is that the biden administration is totally allowed to modify or slow roll down the CSO. Still, the trial run will probably happen in the first half of the new year

Significant vaccination likely in q2
Private vaccines also likely
‘Vaccine only’ cruises a realistic option, in q2/q3
Some yolo option possible beforehand.

Unlike the Airlines sector which has benefited from the bailouts there has been nothing done for the cruise industry so they would be very keen to return back to business as soon as possible. While the CDC has upgraded its risk for Covid 19 to very high. I doubt whether that will really stop people. However the CDC requires ships to be certified which might take some time before they sail. https://www.cruiseindustrynews.com/cruise-news/24032-when-the-major-cruise-lines-plan-to-restart-service-3.html https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/pdf/CDC-Conditional-Sail-Order_10_30_2020-p.pdf

Carnival has cancelled all US cruises through the end of February and has moved the launch of it's new Mardi Gras ship to mid-April. The priority of this event's rescheduling and not postponement likely indicates the company is beginning to think resuming operations is a possibility in the near term. Combined with the roll out of two vaccines in the US in the last two weeks there are probably multiple avenues for the company to start sailing again. These include getting their frontline employees vaccinated and opening cruises only to those that have been immunized. This paves a narrow way forward to get approval to resume operations before operations to both get the required staff set, as well as sell enough tickets to make it worthwhile. On the other hand, a less involved approach would be just waiting for approval and at which point April through June makes sense. Any first sails between October and the end of 2021 would likely be the result of company financial difficulty or bankruptcy vice any COVID related concerns.

The current no-cruise order lasts until February 2021.  Vaccinations and a better federal response to the pandemic following the inauguration of the Biden administration will result in substantial drop in case counts, deaths and hospitalizations.  The CDC has issued guidance for safe sailing and European cruise lines, which have continued to operate.  This will provide a model for Carnival and other U.S. operators.  Carnival will be aggressive to reopen.  Risks to this prediction include:  vaccine not effective as predicted or other cause of worsening pandemic; Carnival Corporation bankruptcy or liquidation.

Vaccines rolling out aggressively and these businesses can't wait to start sailing again.  Airplanes are flying, trains are running, and buses haven't stopped, so they can probably make a strong case to start cruising again.  Ofc things could get worse with mutated strains etc, but I think they're near the end zone re: being able to cruise again

They need to run test cruises first - and this should meet the definition of a "ticketed passenger" and can literally sail in circles - or go to one of the handful of ports that might reopen.  I know the goal is to sale ASAP but not sure they can pull off the test cruise until the 2nd quarter of the year.  Cruises at least for now are cancelled until at least through early 2021 it seems. The company is selling cruises for March 2021 sailings - but those could easily be cancelled which right now is my base case.

This will likely depend on vaccination efforts and percentages of people who have received the vaccine by this time.  A realistic timeframe would be early/late Summer as cruise companies will likely push for regulations allowing them to make some profit in the summer holiday season.

Vance Gulliksen, spokesperson for Carnival Cruise Line, told USA TODAY that all sailings scheduled to depart from U.S. ports until March have been canceled. 
"We had cancelled all voyages through Feb. 2021 with the exception of Miami, Port Canaveral and Galveston," Gulliksen added. "Those are now cancelled too and (the) Mardi Gras inaugural cruise has been pushed back from Feb. 6 to April 24." 
Christine Duffy, president of Carnival Cruise Line, apologized to passengers in a release provided by Gulliksen.
“We apologize to our guests but we must continue to take a thoughtful, deliberate and measured approach as we map out our return to operations in 2021,” Duffy, said.  “Our commitment to the health and safety of our guests, crew and the communities we visit is at the forefront of our decisions and operations.”
Likely that by summer there will be enough people vaccinated to make a safe sailing viable.

Given limited rollout of vaccine, I am projecting a spring to summer first cruise.  While vaccination for passengers might be optional, I believe it will be required for crew. If we are looking at a two jab protocol, 21 days apart, plus an extra two weeks to gain full immunity, spring would be earliest, summer much more likely.

The CDC framework for conditional sailing is onerous.  I do not believe any shionsails from US port until it is lifted.  According to the framework all embarking passengers and crew must be tested prior to embarking so vaccination certificates won't help reduce the burden.  To me this  forecast question is analagous to when will the CDC declare the pandemic over.
Here is link to CDC order https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/pdf/CDC-Conditional-Sail-Order_10_30_2020-p.pdf&ved=2ahUKEwiVhY_UvdPtAhXrRt8KHbFDBYEQFjAJegQIIxAB&usg=AOvVaw3D4rylidpZvPDwkmHz6fTH
Framework starts on page 20.

I think by April 1st, there will be enough people who have been vaccinated willing to go on a cruise. I anticipate that Carnival will mandate proof of vaccination and some form of good health attestation in order to get on the cruise.

The CDC's conditional sailing certificates involve a lot of hoops and requirements that can cause delays, on top of an undefined timeline on the CDC's part (and I expect the agency to not be necessarily prioritizing cruises). Questions around vaccine requirements and how cruise lines react.

I just had our family Jan 17 departure cancelled.  This is the 3rd time in 2020 that a cancellation has happened always moving the departure date forward.  Now the target is March. We will see if they get it right in 2021.
